Award.AwardTitle: ISE Pathways: Audemes, Metaphors and Aural Games: A Pathways Project to Make STEM Engaging for the Blind and Visually Impaired

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project, from Indiana University Purdue University Indianapolis (IUPUI), investigates the design, development and dissemination of metaphoric aural sound symbols (audemes), audeme dictionary and riddle audeme games to teach scientific concepts to 75-100 students who are blind and visually impaired (BVI). A number of research questions are included. How do audemes and sequences function as metaphors of STEM concepts? Which audeme game structures and strategies work best to engage BVI students? How do audemes and audeme games impact STEM education?

The audeme-to-concept-to-audeme dictionary will build scientific concepts using standards, state-approved science textbooks, teachers and students. They will also examine secondary words that are associated with the science concepts by mining textbooks, identifying tertiary concepts, and establishing a preliminary dictionary of audemes. A team of education, students and professionals who are experts will design the audemes after multiple iterations. A control and experimental group of students will test the audemes through traditional methods and audeme games. Students will complete a pre and post test of scientific concepts with repeated measures ANOVA to examine changes on student scores from the control and experimental groups.

This work using audemes to teach scientific concepts will make contributions to BVI, learning disabilities, and general population students. Audemes and audeme games have the potential for broad implementation in both formal and informal settings for computers, mobile, and other networked platforms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant we received (ISE Pathways: Audemes, Metaphors and Aural Games: A Pathways Project to Make STEM Engaging for the Blind and Visually Impaired) was instrumental in allowing us to explore an innovative approach to STEM learning for blind and visually impaired students. Simply stated, this approach leverages the ability of students to recognize and easily remember meaningful sounds from the real world, which we will call semantic sounds, and to use this ability to associate these sounds with STEM content. For our purposes, semantic sound does NOT include speech or abstract beeps and tones made by various machines. Semantic sounds are particularly memorable when presented as brief collages, combinations of two or more semantic sounds  with perhaps a few seconds of music to form what we call "audemes." When students collaborate with teachers and researchers to design audemes to signify certaibn STEM concepts, then play casual games with audemes, this significantly improves classroom outcomes. 

For example, the sounds of hammering and sawing can be easily recognized in a 4-second audeme, and students easily associate this audeme with the idea of "construction" or perhaps "carpentry." If we add the opening notes "da-da-da-DUM" of Beethoven's 5th Symphony to this audeme, and discuss with students how this musical theme signifies "important" or "monumental," then students can interpret the new audeme to mean the larger concept of "engineering" (i.e. "monumental contruction"). The payoff: When facts and ideas are presented verbally in conjunction with this audemes, students score better on classroom tests of this material. Because many STEM concepts are not obviously associated with specific sounds, the interpretative process for audemes often involves a fair degree of metaphor or even humorous associations between concept and sound. For example, the audeme for "plate tectonics" contains the sounds of dinner plates clattering and breaking. 

Our team worked with 15 visually impaired high school students over the course of a year, with a veteran classroom teacher at the Indiana School for the Blind and Visually Impaired (ISBVI), using standard tests that the teacher had developed over her 20 year experience. Using a repeating sequence of 2 weeks WITH audeme games, followed by 1 week WITHOUT, we found that student test scores were often dramatically better after the second WITH week, with a difference in scores that sometimes were as great as 25-30 percentage points. This effect was particularly strong with students with poor to average academic records (visually impaired students often have other cognitive or psychological challenges). 

Over the past three years, we have developed a website that offers a dictionary of audemes, https://audemes.org/dictionary_2014/dictionary.html# along with an audeme riddle game that offers sequences of audemes and challenges the player to decipher a given sequence to signify a STEM concept. https://audemes.org/audemeGridGame/index.html

We have also communicated with and visited other schools for the blind, hoping to recruit other STEM teachers to use audemes in their classes.
